maptool.urbs_editor.routes.urbs_setup()

called when the urbs editor window is first opened

Returns:

path to the html file for the current window

Return type:

string

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.urbsSetupProperties()

on page load the frontend fetches the json file containing parameter names, types, default values etc for generation and maintenance of the editor environment

Returns:

json containing all data information necessary for setting up the urbs editor GUI

Return type:

dict

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.retrieveEditableNetwork()

on opening of the urbs setup view the js code requests full information of the previously selected network we return the network with previously chosen and session-dependant plz, kcid and bcid with all features

Returns:

a json filled with geoJSON featureCollections created from the network selected in previous steps

Return type:

dict

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.retrieveDemandProfilesForSetup()

Pre-defined demand profiles are extracted from the csv template and sent to the frontend here

Returns:

a dict containing all demand profiles

Return type:

dict

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.formatTransmissionSetup()

transmission data is extracted from the csv template and sent to the frontend here. We also send the previously saved sn_mva value for generation of the default kont

Returns:

a dict containing all trafo data and the sn_mva of the network trafo chosen in the network editor

Return type:

dict

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.formatProcessSetup()

process data is extracted from the csv template and sent to the frontend here

Returns:

a dict containing all process and process commodity properties

Return type:

dict

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.formatStorageSetup()

storage data is extracted from the csv template and sent to the frontend here

Returns:

a dict containing all storage properties

Return type:

dict

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.formatCommoditySetup()

commodity data is extracted from the csv template and sent to the frontend here

Returns:

a dict containing all commodity properties

Return type:

dict

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.supimProfiles()

Pre-defined supim profiles are extracted from the csv template and sent to the frontend here. Empty spots in the profile are filled with 0 to avoid issues during the pandapower2urbs step

Returns:

a dict containing all supim profiles

Return type:

dict

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.timevareffProfiles()

Pre-defined timevareff profiles are extracted from the csv template and sent to the frontend here

Returns:

a dict containing all timevareff profiles

Return type:

dict

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.find(s, ch)

help function that returns all the index positions of a char in a list used to find which flags were set to 1 in the demand, supim, timevareff checkbox editors

Parameters:

  • s (string) – string of 0s and 1s symbolizing the chosen row of a given profile

  • ch (char) – the symbol we are looking for, generally ‘1’

Returns:

list with indices of the chars in the input string that equal the char we search for

Return type:

list[int]

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.createDFromCheckboxes(json_data, columns)

creates a pandas dataframe that lists all entries of a profile that have been selected for every bus in the network as a string of indices

Parameters:

  • json_data (list[string]) – json with key value pairs of bus indices an lists of strings symbolizing all entries of all profiles

  • columns (list[string]) – list containing the names of all profiles

Returns:

pandas dataframe where profile names are the columns and strings of type “bus_name, column_1_entry_1;column_1_entry_2, column_2_entry_1,,…”

Type:

pandas dataframe

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.createPdp2UrbsDemandCSV()

the frontend returns the aggregated profiles the user chose for each load bus and each type of demand the returned datastructure is changed into a csv that fits the demanded format

Returns:

response indicating successful data transfer

Return type:

JavaScript Fetch API Response

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.createPdp2UrbsBuildingsCSV()

the function takes returned building data for every bus, fetches additional building info from the database and aggregates it into two csv-files

Returns:

response indicating successful data transfer

Return type:

JavaScript Fetch API Response

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.createPdp2UrbsTransmissionCSV()

reshapes returned data and saves it into csv files

Returns:

response indicating successful data transfer

Return type:

JavaScript Fetch API Response

Returns:

response indicating successful data transfer

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.createPdp2SupimCSV()

the frontend returns the aggregated profiles the user chose for each load bus and each type of supim the returned datastructure is changed into a csv that fits the demanded format

Returns:

response indicating successful data transfer

Return type:

JavaScript Fetch API Response

maptool.urbs_editor.routes.switch_conda_environment(env_path, env_name)
maptool.urbs_editor.routes.runPdp2Urbs()

executes pandapower to urbs input file conversion and the urbs run. Due to differences in requirements we create a subprocess that activates the urbs conda environment and executes the program

Returns:

response indicating successful data transfer

Return type:

JavaScript Fetch API Response
